cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Wetlands
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Bird-hipped Dinosaurs (Ornithischia)
Family: Ankylosaurs (Ankylosauridae)
Genus: Ankylosaurus
Species: magniventris
Pea brain: The skull of the Ankylosaurus was nearly 1 m (3 ft) long, but it was so heavily reinforced that there was only room for a very tiny brain!
The Ankylosaurus is one of the bird-hipped dinosaurs, meaning that the skeletal structure of its hips is similar to that of a modern bird's (although the two are not related).
Ankylosaurus means "stiff reptile," which refers to the bony plates that covered its back.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the ankylosaurus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Ankylosaurus lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 80 million years ago. Ankylosaurid fossils have been found in North America and Asia.
The Ankylosaurus had short legs, which limited its speed, but this immense tank of a beast was very agile. Besides its great size and armored plating, the Ankylosaurus' most notable feature was its clublike tail, which it could swing with great force. It could easily defeat even the largest attackers. However, unlike other dinosaurs armed with similar equipment, there is no evidence that Ankylosaurus magniventris used its appendage in tail-to-tail combat with other males during mating season.
Diet: herbivore; height: 1.7 m (5.5 ft) at the hip; length: 6.25 to 9 m (20.5 to 30 ft).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tundra
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Bears (Ursidae)
Genus: Arctodus
Species: simus
The short-faced bear was the biggest bear that ever lived.
It was also the biggest land predator in the Americas during the Ice Age.
The skull and teeth of Arctodus simus were more similar to those of a lion than to today's modern bear.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the short-faced bear in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The short-faced bear lived in the Americas from 1.6 million to 10,000 years ago. Like many other species of ancient megafauna, this giant bear became extinct at the end of the Pleistocene era. Possible causes for its extinction include the extinction of many of the creatures it preyed upon, as well as the development of weapons and hunting techniques by early man.
Arctodus simus was almost twice as big as today's brown bear. With its short muzzle, powerful jaws, and formidable teeth, the short-faced bear was a dominant hunter capable of killing large animals. Its prey likely included bison, deer, elk, and camels. This massive beast may have been more diet conscious than today's full-figured bears: Its long legs and straight toes, while enabling it to run fast, also gave the short-faced bear a more slender profile.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.7 m (5.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, up to 3.4 m (11 ft) when upright; weight: up to 900 kg (2,000 lb).

cell.color: Conservation Status:
Extinct
Wetlands
Madagascar

Class: Birds (Aves)
Order: Ratites (Struthioniformes)
Family: Elephant Birds (Aepyornithidae)
Genus: Aepyornis
Species: maximus
The elephant bird was by far the heaviest bird that ever lived.
BFF (best friends forever): Bones of the elephant bird have often been discovered near bones of the hippopotamus.

At more than 30 cm (12 in) long and with a circumference of over 1 m (3 ft), the elephant bird's eggs were larger than any dinosaur egg discovered to date. A single egg from this bird could feed an entire family!
Aepyornis means "tall bird."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the elephant bird in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The elephant bird lived on the island of Madagascar and may have survived until the arrival of the first humans there. Aepyornis maximus became extinct about 350 years ago, possibly due to deforestation of the island and colonization. Although there is little evidence it was hunted extensively for food, elephant bird eggshells found in fire remains suggest humans probably stole eggs from undefended nests to scramble for breakfast. The explorer Marco Polo wrote of a giant bird that could pick up an elephant, fly high into the air, and then drop it to its death. Although his story may have played a part in giving the elephant bird its name, it was certainly a tall tale. Like the ostrich, the elephant bird was a ratite: It could not fly.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.4 to 2.7 m (8 to 9 ft) tall; weight: up to 450 kg (1,000 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Grassland
Southern Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bodivae)
Genus: Hippotragus
Species: leucophaeus

Are you blue? Although Bluebucks found in museums today show no blue color, its name reflects descriptions of live animals. The blue tone may have come from the combination of its black and yellow hairs and the sheen of its dark skin.
Just four preserved and mounted Bluebuck skins, two skulls, and miscellaneous bones remain in museums from what was a thriving population 2,000 years ago.
Two living relatives of the Bluebuck are the Roan antelope and the Sable antelope, both of which are classified as "horse antelopes" because of their size and horselike bodies.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the bluebuck in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Bluebuck was the first South African mammal species to become extinct in modern history. When European immigrants entered the region in the 17th century, Bluebucks may have already been on the decline. Europeans further thinned Bluebuck populations through hunting and the rapid conversion of grassland to farmland, accelerating the extinction of this already-threatened antelope. The last known Bluebuck was killed by a hunter around 1800.
The Bluebuck, also called the blue antelope, looked similar to other species in the antelope family. It had two medium-length sweeping horns, no mane, and a darker coat on top with a white underbelly. Hippotragus leucophaeus lived in the southwestern coastal area of South Africa and roamed the region's well-watered grasslands. The delicate Bluebuck may have preferred blossoms to bushes: According to modern research, the particular grasslands that this species inhabited were -- and are today -- some of the most biologically rich lands on Earth. Not only is the soil especially fertile, but the plant life is also colored by an abundance of flowers, mostly of the daisy family.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1 m (3.5 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 160 kg (350 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Grassland
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Camels (Camelidae)
Genus: Titanotylopus
Species: spatulus
The giant camel was nearly twice the size of the modern camel. Appropriately, it was originally called Gigantocamelus.
Titanotylopus spatulus's large canine teeth were different from those of today's camel. And it had one other sad difference: The giant camel had no lacrimal vacuities -- it could not cry.
Titanotylopus means "giant knobby-foot," a reference to this big camel's size and its pad-toed feet. Spatulus refers to its broad, flat (spatulalike) incisor teeth.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the giant camel in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Titanotylopus spatulus lived in North America in the Miocene and Pleistocene eras. An extremely large ancestor of the modern camel, the giant camel traveled widely across the United States. Fossils have been found in Texas, Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and Arizona. It resembled the modern camel and included standard camel luggage -- its well-known hump. Its hump and padded toes were probably two or three times the size of today's camels.
Diet: herbivore; size: 3.5 m (11.5 ft) tall at the shoulder.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores Carnivora
Family: Cats (Felidae)
Genus: Smilodon
Species: fatalis
The better to eat you with: Smilodon fatalis could open its mouth far wider than today's lion -- 120 degrees to the lion's mere 65 degrees.
The saber-toothed cat's canine teeth were up to 18 cm (7 in) long -- much longer than the blade of an average steak knife.
Its name means "knife tooth."
Many Smilodon fatalis fossils have been found in the La Brea Tar Pits in Los Angeles, California.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the saber-toothed cat in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Saber-toothed cats lived in both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, beginning about 40 million years ago. They became extinct around 11,000 years ago.
The saber-toothed cat, commonly called the saber-toothed tiger, was a large, powerful cat about the size of a lion. It had long, curved canine teeth shaped like sabers. Scientists have identified the fossils of three kinds of saber-toothed cats that coexisted in North America. The best known was Smilodon, recognized by its long, finely serrated canine teeth. Because its short, muscular legs provided power but not speed, Smilodon fatalis probably fed on slow-moving prey such as American mastodons. It would use its vicious, knifelike canines to deliver a fatal wound to the belly, throat, or neck of its prey. Some scientists believe the size of a saber-toothed cat's teeth may have helped it establish dominance among other cats or attract a mate, similar to the function of horns and antlers in other male animals.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.2 m (4 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 200 kg (440 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:

Temperate Forest
Eurasia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed UngulatesArtiodactyla
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Bos
Species: promigenius
No bull! The aurochs' horns could grow up to 1 m (3 ft) long.
Aurochs horns were widely used as drinking vessels for many centuries.
The aurochs was commonly depicted in Paleolithic or Old Stone Age cave paintings found in France and Spain.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the aurochs in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The aurochs, an immense species of wild ox, was a direct ancestor of modern domestic cattle. It was hunted aggressively by humans in part because it competed with domestic cattle for food, but also because its occasional interbreeding with domestic cattle disrupted development of domestic cattle lines. The aurochs population declined as its wild habitat decreased with the growth of farms and cities. The last aurochs died in 1627.
The habitat of Bos primigenius extended across Europe and North Africa to Asia, and was domesticated in Asia around 6000 BC. By 2000 BC, domesticated aurochs appeared in Greece and perhaps in India. This domesticated line eventually spread to Switzerland and Germany, and then to the British Isles. After the late 13th century, most of the aurochs population that remained could be found only in Poland. A few cattle breeds, including Highland cattle from Scotland, resemble their distant relative, the aurochs.
What does the aurochs have in common with today's antelopes, goats, and hippos? They are all even-toed ungulates. "Ungulate" means they have hoofs, and an even-toed ungulate has an even number of hoofs (toes) on each foot, most with two hoofs per foot but some with four.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2 m (6.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, and more than 3 m (10 ft) long; weight: more than 1,000 kg (2,200 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Deer (Cervidae)
Genus: Eucladoceros
Species: dicranios
Growing, growing ... gone: Antlers grow faster than anything else in the animal kingdom, usually reaching their full size in three months before shedding.
This deer's antlers could grow to a combined width of up to 1.7 m (5.6 ft).
Eucladoceros means "well-branched antler."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the bush-antlered deer in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Eucladoceros dicranios thrived across Europe and Asia during the Pleistocene era. It became extinct about 50,000 years ago. The first bush-antlered deer fossil was discovered in Italy in 1841.
This ancient, regal-looking deer was crowned with the most elaborate set of antlers in the deer family. The two pedicles branched out from the top of its head, each ending in twelve tines. As with other antlered creatures, the bush-antlered deer used its massive antler array not only as a weapon against rivals but also to attract a mate.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.8 m (6 ft) tall at the shoulder, up to 2.5 m (8 ft) long.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tropical Rainforest
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Deinonychus
Species: antirrhopus
Deinonychus means "terrible claw" -- an apt description of one of its most terrifying features!
Deinonychus was the most important dinosaur fossil ever discovered. It changed scientist's belief that dinosaurs were slow and plodding, and introduced the idea that some may have been warm-blooded.
This dinosaur's bones are hollow, similar to those of a modern bird.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock Deinonychus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Deinonychus antirrhopus lived during the Cretaceous Period. Until its discovery, dinosaurs were thought to be slow-moving herbivores. By contrast, this predator was swift and agile, and probably hunted its prey in packs. Deinonychus had an enormous claw on the second toe of each hind foot. Scientists once thought it used the claw in a slashing movement to kill its prey. New research shows this dinosaur more likely used it to stab and hold down prey while tearing it to shreds with its razor-sharp teeth. In any case, when Deinonychus is on the rampage -- look out!
Diet: carnivore; size: 3 m (10 ft) long; weight: 80 kg (180 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tropical Rainforest
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Crocodiles (Crocodilia)
Family: Alligators (Alligatoroidea)
Genus: Deinosuchus
Species: hatcheri
Deinosuchus' skull alone was more than 2 m (6.7 ft) long.

Unlike today's crocodile species, which tend to live in either freshwater or saltwater habitats, Deinosuchus fossils have been found in freshwater and saltwater environments, suggesting this creature enjoyed both.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock Deinosuchus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Deinosuchus hatcheri lived in Texas during the Upper Cretaceous Period. It belonged to the group Eusuchia, the true crocodiles. Deinosuchus was larger than even the biggest of the modern living reptiles (the saltwater crocodile of Australia and Southern and Southeast Asia), and was one of the largest crocodilians that ever existed. In fact, scientists continue to argue which crocodilian was the largest: Deinosuchus or Sarcosuchus, another immense creature that lived in South America and Africa.
Deinosuchus was much like the modern crocodile. It very likely lived in similar habitats, followed equivalent mating patterns, and exhibited the same hunting characteristics of today's crocs, including the dramatic grab-and-roll technique for which crocodiles are famous. But its diet probably included one treat today's crocodiles never get to snack on -- fresh dinosaur meat!
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 12 m (40 ft) long.

Class: Synapsids (Synapsida)
Order: Spined Lizards (Pelycosauria)
Family: Carnivorous Pelycosaurs(Sphenacodontidae)
Genus: Dimetrodon
Species: angelensis
In spite of its size and appearance, Dimetrodon wasn't a dinosaur; it is classified as a pelycosaur and lived millions of years before dinosaurs even existed.
Lizard? No, it isn't related to lizards, either; it is classified as having been more mammalian than reptilian.
Its sail didn't just make Dimetrodon look cool, it actually made it be cool by regulating body temperature.
Dimetrodon means "two-measure teeth," referring to its teeth of two different sizes.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the dimetrodon in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Dimetrodon angelensis lived during the Permian Period and became extinct about 256 million years ago. The tall sail on its back, its trademark feature, increased the size of its surface skin by up to 50 percent. This flashy sail may have been used to attract a mate. Unlike the free-floating bony structures found on the backs of some ancient creatures, the spines that held up Dimetrodon's sail were attached to individual vertebra. Dimetrodon was one of the first animals to have teeth of different sizes, which made it easier to eat a variety of animals. Although it likely chased its prey on land, Dimetrodon may also have waded in streams to catch fish. Dimetrodon may have been manner conscious: Although many similarly sized creatures swallowed their prey whole, Dimetrodon chewed its meals before swallowing.
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 3.5 m (11.5 ft) long.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Diprotodonts (Diprotodontia)
Family: Marsupials Diprotodontidae
Genus: Diprotodon
Species: optatum
This ancient Australian creature was the biggest marsupial that ever lived. It was related to the kangaroo but was the size of a present-day rhinoceros!
Its skull alone was about 1 m (3 ft) in length.
Diprotodon means "two first teeth." It had flat teeth by its cheeks for chewing plants and long front teeth for cutting and digging up plants.
Modern relatives of Diprotodon include the wombat and the koala.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the diprotodon in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Diprotodon optatum became extinct some 40,000 to 50,000 years ago, due to a combination of causes that probably included climate change, hunting by early man, and human use of fire, which changed the landscape and ecosystem. Fossils of these animals have been found only in Australian Pleistocene deposits.
Like the kangaroo, Diprotodon had a pouch it used to carry its young. Unlike the kangaroo, it used all four legs for walking. Its head was similar in shape to that of today's wombat, and its huge body ended in a tiny, thin tail. This stocky marsupial may have been community minded, living with others of its kind in herds.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.7 m (5.6 ft) tall, 3 m (10 ft) long from nose to tail; weight: up to 2,500 kg (5,500 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tropical Rainforest
Mauritius

Class: Birds (Aves)
Order: Pigeons (Columbiformes)
Family: Dodos (Raphidae)
Genus: Raphus
Species: cucullatus

Stone soup: Known to have subsisted largely on fruit, accounts by sailors who visited the island indicate this bird may also have eaten fish as well as another, less-popular menu item -- rocks. Scientists speculate the rocks may have aided digestion.
This bird's name was likely derived from the Portuguese word duodo, meaning 'silly' or 'stupid.'
The obscure dodo became better known to many people after its appearance in Lewis Carroll's fanciful Alice's Adventures in Wonderland in 1865.
The dodo's living relatives include pigeons and doves.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the dodo in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The dodo was a large, flightless bird that once inhabited the forests of the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean. Larger than a turkey, weighing up to 23 kg (50 lb), this fruit-eating bird had a large hooked bill, undeveloped wings, and short, thick, yellow legs. It laid a single, large egg in a ground nest made of grass. The dodo was first reported in 1598 by Dutch colonizers, who characterized it as sluggish and unafraid of humans. Having lived as the largest creature in an island environment without predators, the dodo didn't recognize humans as a threat. This soon changed as humans became the most significant predator of these flightless creatures. Dodos were last observed in 1681. Their precipitous extinction is also attributed in part to animals imported to Mauritius by settlers, including pigs, cats, rats, and monkeys, which destroyed many of the dodo nests, eggs, and young. Until recently only a few fossil bones of the bird had been discovered, and, even though it existed during modern times, very little was known about this strange creature. In 2005, Dutch researchers found a large trove of dodo bones, including full adults and chicks, on Mauritius that will aid in uncovering more details of this bird.
The dodo is best known for its humorous appearance. It had a large, oddly shaped, hooked bill; undeveloped wings similar to those found on penguins, unsuitable for flight; short yellow legs; and a silly tuft of feathers on its tail end. Although most depictions of Raphus cucullatus show this shy bird as being fat and stocky, the wild dodo may have been quite slim, about half the size of its commonly reported girth. Dodos were introduced to the general public after being imported to Europe, where, it is speculated, they became more rotund in captivity.
Diet: herbivore; size: about 1 m (3 ft) tall; weight: up to 23 kg (50 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:

South America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Edentates (Edentata)
Family: Armadillos (Glyptodontidae)
Genus: Doedicurus
Species: clavicaudatus
Doedicurus was about the size of the modern armadillo's most common predator: the small family automobile.
Doedicurus means "pestle tail." It was so named because the bony tail without its spikes resembled a pestle.
Some Doedicurus fossils have dents in their carapaces, indicating that males may have used their tails to fight one another during mating season.
Modern relatives of the Doedicurus include the armadillo, sloth, and anteater.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock Doedicurus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Doedicurus, an immense armadillo, was one of the Pleistocene megafauna that thrived in the southern Americas until 15,000 years ago. It probably succumbed to climate changes during the Holocene extinction at the beginning of the modern era. Doedicurus clavicaudatus inhabited woodlands and grasslands, grazing on a variety of vegetation and possibly digging for roots and tubers.
Unlike modern armadillos, Doedicurus had a long, bony tail that ended in a dangerous, macelike array of spikes. Its domed carapace of 1800 armored plates was 2.5 cm (1 in) thick and covered a protective layer of fat, which made it nearly impervious to attack. Its enormous size limited the number of predators that could take it on. But its size could also be a detriment: Doedicurus was a heavy, lumbering glyptodont that could get wedged between rocks and stuck in mud, leaving it defenseless and vulnerable to attack by predators such as Smilodon, the saber-toothed cat. The two beasts likely crossed paths after South America collided with North America around 2.5 million years ago, at which time northern carnivores such as Smilodon headed south while southerners such as Doedicurus migrated north, in an event called the Great Faunal Interchange.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.5 m (5 ft) tall, 4 m (13 ft) long; weight: 1,500 kg (3,306 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Elephants (Proboscidea)
Family: Elephants (Elephantidae)
Genus: Elephas
Species: falconeri
The dwarf Sicilian elephant was the smallest elephant that ever lived.
A full-grown dwarf Sicilian elephant probably weighed about the same as a newborn Asian elephant.
Strange relations: The sea cow, a marine mammal, is a distant relative of the elephant. It broke from the proboscidian line about 40 million years ago.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the dwarf Sicilian elephant in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Elephas falconeri lived during the Pleistocene Period and became extinct during the last glaciation. While many extinct Pleistocene creatures were extremely large versions of animals living today, some, like the dwarf Sicilian elephant, were much smaller than their modern counterparts -- in this case, the modern Asian elephant. This tiny pachyderm probably evolved from a much larger European elephant species that migrated south when the Mediterranean Sea was at a very low level. When the sea level rose, Elephas falconeri became isolated on the island of Sicily. Like some other ancient animals, it underwent a process called "insular dwarfism": Animals isolated on islands can become smaller over many generations if a lack of predators makes it unnecessary to maintain a large size and smallness is an advantage if food is not abundant. Dwarf elephants also lived elsewhere in the Mediterranean -- on Malta, Cyprus, Crete, Sardinia, some of the Greek islands, and southern Italy.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1 m (3 ft) tall; weight: 100 kg (220 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tropical Rainforest
China

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Primates (Primata)
Family: Hominids (Hominidae)
Genus: Gigantopithecus
Species: blacki
Gigantopithecus was the biggest ape that ever lived.
Its closest living relative is the orangutan.
Some people maintain that Gigantopithecus did not become extinct but migrated across the frozen Bering Strait to North America, to become the basis of legends about the Sasquatch, or "Bigfoot."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock Gigantopithecus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Gigantopithecus lived in Southeast Asia until about 100,000 years ago. This giant ape's extinction was likely due to a number of factors, including climate change and competition for the bamboo that made up the bulk of its diet. The emergence of early hominids, such as Homo erectus, may have added to the competition.
This big ape was probably a ground dweller, as it was much too heavy to have moved through the trees like today's monkeys. It likely supported itself on its knuckles as it walked. In spite of its ferocious looks, Gigantopithecus blacki wouldn't hurt a fly: It was a vegetarian. This immense beast had to consume huge quantities of plants in order to fuel its massive system, and it had just the right kind of teeth for the job -- large molars housed in big jaws. In fact, the only fossils so far recovered of this creature have been jawbones and teeth. Scientists have used these fossils to extrapolate the size, shape, and habits of this immense creature, largely by comparisons to fossils of similar species.
Diet: herbivore; size: 3 m (10 ft) tall; weight: up to 500 kg (1,100 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:

East Africa

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Bird-hipped Dinosaurs (Ornithischia)
Family: Stegosaurs (Stegosauridae)
Genus: Stegosaurus
Species: kentrosaurus
Hoofin' it: Rather than the standard claws found on most dinosaurs, the unusual feet of the Kentrosaurus were more like hoofs.
The dangerous spikes along its back and tail were up to 0.3 m (1 ft) long.
Kentrosaurus means "pointed lizard."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the kentrosaurus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
This dinosaur of the Jurassic Period became extinct about 150 million years ago. The Kentrosaurus sported heavy armor: It had plates and long spikes along its back and tail, and a spike that protruded from each shoulder, which it used to protect itself from predators. Unlike similar ornamentation found on other dinosaurs, the Kentrosaurus' plates and spikes were not connected to its bone structure. This slow-moving dinosaur walked on all four feet, but it could rise up on its hind legs to reach higher vegetation.
Diet: herbivore; size: 5.5 m (18 ft) long; weight: 1,814 kg (4000 lb).

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Cats (Felidae)
Genus: Panthera
Species: leo
Subspecies: spelaea
No lyin'! Panthera leo spelaea was the biggest cat that ever roamed the Earth -- about 30 percent bigger than the modern African lion.
Cave lions may have existed in the Balkans just 2,000 years ago, long after the species disappeared from most of Europe and Asia.
Paleolithic man painted images of the cave lion -- in caves.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the cave lion in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The cave lion lived during the Pleistocene era, and its habitat included much of Europe, Africa, and Asia until its extinction around 10,000 years ago. Humans successfully hunted it and may have contributed to its extinction. The extinction of many of the animals Panthera leo spelaea preyed upon may have hastened the disappearance of this species. Also called the European or Eurasian cave lion, this massive cat lived in natural caves during the winter. Its size, speed, and strength made it a formidable predator. Its prey included such herbivores as primitive horses and bison, and possibly even humans.
The male cave lion was unadorned with the stylish ruff of mane and matching tail worn by today's modern lions, going instead for the sleeker look of a major predator. Its one concession to fashion could be found in its coat, which it probably changed with the seasons, becoming white in winter to blend into its snowy habitat.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.5 m (4.9 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 320 kg (705 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Elephants (Proboscidea)
Family: Mastodons (Mammutidae)
Genus: Mammut
Species: americanum
This large, shaggy mammal may have enjoyed spending time in lakes and swamps.
Big nose? The American mastodon is of the order Proboscidea, meaning "long-snouted."
Its coat could grow up to 18 cm (7 in) long.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the American mastodon in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
This elephantlike creature roamed the spruce forests of North America until about 12,500 years ago, when it became extinct. Early man hunted the mastodon and may have contributed to its extinction. Well-preserved American mastodon fossils have been found throughout North America, especially in the northeastern and Great Lakes regions of the United States. Part of the extinct genus Mammut, American mastodons belong to the family Mammutidae, which originated in North Africa 30 to 40 million years ago.
Although Mammut americanum -- with its shaggy brown coat, stocky legs, huge head, and flexible trunk -- looked like and is distantly related to the woolly mammoth, it's a distinctly different animal. The American mastodon was distinguished by nearly horizontal tusks and conical-shaped teeth. Its long tusks helped it to break tree branches, and its blunt teeth were adept at chewing the tough leaves that were a central part of its food intake.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.5 to 3 m (8 to 10 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: 3,500 to 5,400 kg (7,700 to 12,000 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Wetlands
Asia

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Lizard-hipped Dinosaurs (Saurischia)
Family: Theropods (Theropoda)
Genus: Protarchaeopteryx
Species: robusta
Protarchaeopteryx means "ancient early wing," a reference to this dinosaur's connection to birds.
Which came first? The discovery of Protarchaeopteryx robusta reinforced the theory that birds evolved from dinosaurs.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the protarchaeopteryx in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Protarchaeopteryx lived from the Jurassic to the Cretaceous Period, and became extinct about 121 million years ago. This groundbreaking dinosaur was only recently discovered: It was first unearthed in the mid-1990s. The feathered Protarchaeopteryx looked more like a bird than a dinosaur. In fact, it is considered by some scientists to be a missing link in the evolution between dinosaurs and birds. Although Protarchaeopteryx robusta could not fly, its long legs suggest it could run very fast.
Diet: unknown; size: 1 m (3 ft) long; weight: 4 kg (10 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Savannah
East Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Odd-Toed Ungulates (Perissodactyla)
Family: Horses/Asses/Zebra (Equidae)
Genus: Equus
Species: quagga
The quagga's name comes from a native South African word for zebra, the sound of which is an onomatopoeia -- it resembles the animal's barking call.
Anything but plaid: Unlike the zebra, whose entire body is striped, the quagga's stripes clothed only the front of its body.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can not adopt a quagga. You may breed quaggas, but the only way to acquire one is at the
Extinct Research Lab,
or by unlocking it with the Extinct Release Program award.
Quaggas were native to southern Africa and were plentiful until the late 1600s, when European colonists in Africa hunted them for their meat and hides, and also for sport. By the late 1870s, the wild quagga population was wiped out. What remained had been sent to zoos in Europe. The last quagga died in captivity in 1883, at the Amsterdam Zoo.
Quaggas were likely sociable creatures that moved in herds of 30 to 50 animals. They grazed on desert grasses and sometimes traveled in single file. Of the three species of
zebras
that exist, Equus quagga was related to the plains zebras that roam the grasslands of Africa today.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.4 m (4.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, 2.5 m (8 ft) long.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tundra
Eurasia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Odd-Toed Ungulates (Perissodactyla)
Family: Rhinoceros (Rhinocerotidae)
Genus: Coelodonta
Species: antiquitatis
The woolly rhinoceros' longest horn could grow up to 1 m (3 ft) in length.
Like modern-day rhinos, the woolly rhinoceros lived alone or in small family groups.
Possibly reflecting its importance to early humans, many images of the woolly rhinoceros have been found painted on cave walls.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the woolly rhinoceros in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Early humans hunted the woolly rhinoceros, and it became extinct about 8,000 to 10,000 years ago. Many frozen remains of the woolly rhinoceros have been discovered, some well preserved in oil-saturated soil.
This member of the Pleistocene megafauna was similar in build to the modern rhinoceros, but it was well insulated with fat and covered in a thick layer of long, shaggy hair, which helped it survive in the cold, snowy conditions found across northern Europe and Asia. Coelodonta antiquitatis had two horns, one longer than the other. The woolly rhinoceros may have been a gardener at heart: It mowed the grass with its short teeth and sometimes using its long horn to dig up plants for dinner.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2 m (6 ft) tall at the shoulder, 3 to 3.8 m (10 to 12.5 ft) long.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Savannah
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Giraffes (Giraffidae)
Genus: Sivatherium
Species: maurusium
How's the weather up there? Sivatherium was the largest member of the giraffe family that ever lived.
Its ossicones were much larger than those of a modern giraffe, but its neck and legs were much shorter.
The saber-toothed cat may have been the Sivatherium's principal predator.
Its closest living relative is the okapi, or forest giraffe.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Sivatherium in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Sivatherium's habitat extended from Africa to Europe and southern Asia, until it became extinct about 8,000 years ago. Although it was a member of the giraffe family, Sivatherium maurusium looked more like a heavily built antelope, and had a wide, almost mooselike snout. Unlike the long and lean giraffe, the Sivatherium's body was stout and its legs were relatively short. Its powerful shoulders and short, strong neck supported a broad, heavy head with wide ossicones, or hair-covered horns. Not content with one set of ossicones, the Sivatherium had an extra pair of bony growths that protruded above its eyes.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.2 m (7 ft) tall at the shoulder.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Scrub
South America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Edentates (Xenarthra)
Family: Sloths (Megatheriidae)
Genus: Megatherium
Species: americanum
Megatherium means "giant beast," a good name for a sloth the size of a modern bull elephant!
It had huge, curving claws that were up to 30 cm (12 in) long.
The shape of its claws forced Megatherium americanum to walk on the sides of its feet, like modern anteaters.
Its living relatives include the tree sloth, armadillo, and anteater.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the giant ground sloth in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 5-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The giant ground sloth became extinct about 8,000 years ago. It ranged across the Americas, from Texas all the way south to Argentina. This gigantic, fur-covered sloth was a quadruped, but it could walk on its hind legs by steadying itself with its enormous tail. Some scientists believe this sloth may have been omnivorous, scavenging meat from animals killed by saber-toothed cats and other prehistoric predators. Megatherium americanum had long claws which it used to pull down leafy branches and dig up plants. With its immense size and formidable claws, the giant ground sloth had little to fear in the way of predators and could feed unhindered during the day.
Diet: herbivore/omnivore; size: 6 m (20 ft) tall when upright; weight: 3,800 kg (8,400 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Bird-hipped Dinosaurs (Ornithischia)
Family: Stegosaurs (Stegosauridae)
Genus: Stegosaurus
Species: stenops
In brain-to-size ratio, the Stegosaurus had the smallest brain of any dinosaur. It was roughly the size of a walnut!
Its name means "narrow-faced roof lizard," which may refer to the early theory that the Stegosaurus' trademark plates lay flat against its back, like a roof.
Stegosaurus was declared the state dinosaur of Colorado in 1982.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the stegosaurus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Stegosaurus lived during the Jurassic Period and was the only plated dinosaur ever found in western North America. It had 17 attractive, triangular dermal plates, similar to those found in modern crocodiles and some lizards, along the length of its spine. Stegosaurus stenops' weapon of choice was its tail, which was adorned with four vicious-looking spikes. In spite of its impressive weaponry, it became extinct about 145 million years ago.
Diet: herbivore; size: 7 m (23 ft) long; weight: 2,722 kg (6,000 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Archosauria
Order: Saurischia
Family: Tyrannosauridae
Genus: Stokesosaurus
Species: clevelandi
The Stokesosaurus was named after a geologist whose last name was Stokes.
Its fossils have been found only in the state of Utah, in the United States.
Known for its lack of visual acuity, sometimes the Stokesosaurus will put on glasses when it can't see.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the stokesosaurus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
This theropod lived during the Jurassic Period and became extinct about 145 million years ago. The Stokesosaurus is a mysterious creature; very little is known about this dinosaur. In fact, only a few bones, including a hip bone, a few vertebrae, and a partial braincase, have been found so far. Its sole claim to fame: Stokesosaurus clevelandi may be related to the very popular Tyrannosaurus rex.
Diet: carnivore; size: 2.1 m (7 ft) high, 4 m (13 ft) long.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Temperate Forest
Tasmania

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Dasyuromorphia)
Family: Marsupials (Thylacinidae)
Genus: Thylacinus
Species: cynocephalus
The thylacine was the largest carnivorous marsupial that ever existed.
Thylacinus cynocephalus is also called the Tasmanian tiger and Tasmanian wolf.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the thylacine in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Native to Australia and New Guinea, the thylacine also inhabited the island of Tasmania (south of eastern Australia). Thylacine cynocephalus's extinction was due to several causes, including disease and competition by wild dogs, but most notably it was hunted by farmers and bounty hunters, who saw it as a pest. The last known thylacine died in an Australian zoo in 1936.
Although the thylacine was a marsupial, it was the size of a small wolf and looked like a dog -- except for the parts that looked like a kangaroo: It had a tapered hind end and a long, stiff, kangaroolike tail, which accounted for about half its length. It could balance upright and hop on its hind legs, stabilized by its rigid tail, and also had a ready-made pouch on its abdomen in which it carried its young. Its short, coarse, brownish hair was reminiscent of yet another animal, with its distinctive black tigerlike stripes across the back. While the kangaroo is an herbivore, the thylacine's diet was markedly wolflike: It was a carnivore.
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 1.3 m (4 ft) long, including the tail; weight: 15 to 33 kg (33 to 66 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Utahraptor
Species: ostrommaysorum
The Utahraptor's famous claw could grow up to 23 cm (almost 9 in) long!
It was the largest member of the Dromaeosauridae family.
Utahraptor means "Utah thief."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the utahraptor in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Utahraptor lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 119 million years ago. Utahraptor ostrommaysorum is the only known species of Utahraptor. This theropod walked upright on massive hind limbs, and, like its cousins Deinonychus and Velociraptor, it featured a menacing claw on the second toe of each foot that it used to kill its prey. Utahraptor walked with the sharp claws raised above the ground to protect its most valuable weapon.
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 6.5 m (22 ft) long; weight: 700 kg (1,500 lb).

cell.color:

Central Asia

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Velociraptor
Species: mongoliensis
Although the Velociraptors' hands were very dexterous, don't worry -- it still couldn't open your bedroom door.
The Velociraptor is a Dromeaosaridae, which means "running lizard."

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the velociraptor in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Velociraptor mongoliensis lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 70 million years ago. It belongs to a group of dinosaurs that has been linked to Archaeopteryx -- also known as ancient birds. In fact, these dinosaurs are often referred to as "raptors," a term that is also used to describe modern birds of prey such as vultures and falcons. Much smaller than its immense cousin Deinonychus, wolf-size Velociraptor walked on its hind legs and used its long tail for balance. It was agile and quick. Although its hindquarters were much larger than its puny arms, the Velociraptor made up for its lack of size with nimble hands that it used to grasp its struggling dinner. Velociraptor is best known for the vicious, curved claw on each of its hind feet that it used to kill its prey.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.8 m (6 ft) long; weight: 45 kg (100 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Grassland
Falkland Islands

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Canines (Canidae)
Genus: Dusicyon
Species: australis
Instead of howling like the foxes it resembled, the Warrah is said to have barked like a dog.
It was the only mammal native to the Falkland Islands, off the southern coast of Argentina, and was also known as the Falkland Islands Fox.
Its name means "foolish dog of the south" and refers to the Warrah's apparent lack of fear of humans.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Warrah in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Despite the Warrah's probable diet of penguins, ground-nesting birds, grubs and insects, and vegetation, immigrants to the animal's native Falkland Islands saw it as a threat to domestic cattle and sheep. Its tawny coat was also prized for its thickness. Settlers trapped, poisoned, and shot Dusicyon australis in large numbers. The last known Warrah was killed in 1876.
With its reddish-brown coat and white-tipped tail, the Warrah resembled other species of fox or a small wolf. Ancient cavemen may have warmed up to this best friend: The Warrah's comparative tameness has led some to suggest that it may have been brought to the Falkland Islands by prehistoric man and domesticated, retaining some of its domestic behavior after the original human inhabitants left.
Diet: carnivore/omnivore; size: 60 cm (24 in) tall at the shoulder.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Savannah
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Pigs (Suidae)
Genus: Metrideochoerus
Species: andrewsi
Pigheaded: Like the modern warthog, the long, wide head of the giant warthog had two pairs of sharp, defensive tusks that pointed sideways and curved upwards, and two pairs of wartlike protuberances.
The giant warthog's habits were also likely to have been similar to those of today's warthog. Usually active during the day, this giant creature probably slept the night away in a burrow.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the giant warthog in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
This extinct genus of pig lived in Africa during the Pleistocene Period. It resembled the modern warthog but was somewhat larger. Based on the shape of its molars, Metridiochoerus andrewsi is believed to have fed, like its modern counterpart, on grass, berries, bark, roots, and carrion. It was likely family oriented, with a social life similar to the modern warthog's: One or two females with young formed small groups, which a male might join briefly during mating season; young males formed bachelor groups, but older males were solitary.
Diet: Omnivore; size: 1.5 m (5 ft) long; weight: up to 160 kg (350 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct (But still killer!)
Tundra
Madagascar

Class: Birds Aves
Order: Sphenisciformes
Family: Spheniscidae
Genus: Eudyptes
Species: omnicidus
Killer penguins love long walks on the frozen beach, sunsets, and pecking other animals to death.
If someone asks you if you want a free penguin, you should say no.
Students of the sciences, killer penguins can often be found lurking in places where they shouldn't be.

LOC_STRING.cell:
Frankly, the Zoopedia doesn't know how you obtained this crazy penguin. Probably some kind of mistake at the Extinct Research Lab. Anyway, don't try getting another one. One of these is enough to mess up your whole zoo!
Killer penguins earned their name by pecking other animals to death. These psychotic penguins are misplaced Tundra animals that were last seen on the island of Madagascar.
With the classic tuxedo look and fiery red eyes, these killers are as aggressive as their name suggests. It is common for them to fight any animal, any time.
Killer penguins will eat just about anything, and because of this, you shouldn't let any of your other animals near them. Ever.
Oh, also, they tend to not like being fenced in, so the Zoopedia hopes you have a solid fence-building team!
If you're looking for a more docile penguin that makes a better zoo resident, check out the
Emperor Penguin
.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Wetlands
North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Bird-hipped Dinosaurs (Ornithischia)
Family: Ankylosaurs (Ankylosauridae)
Genus: Ankylosaurus
Species: magniventris
Pea brain: The skull of the Ankylosaurus was nearly 1 m (3 ft) long, but it was so heavily reinforced that there was only room for a very tiny brain!
The Ankylosaurus is one of the bird-hipped dinosaurs, meaning that the skeletal structure of its hips is similar to that of a modern bird's (although the two are not related).
Ankylosaurus means "stiff reptile," which refers to the bony plates that covered its back.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super ankylosaurus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Ankylosaurus lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 80 million years ago. Ankylosaurid fossils have been found in North America and Asia.
The Ankylosaurus had short legs, which limited its speed, but this immense tank of a beast was very agile. Besides its great size and armored plating, the Ankylosaurus' most notable feature was its clublike tail, which it could swing with great force. It could easily defeat even the largest attackers. However, unlike other dinosaurs armed with similar equipment, there is no evidence that Ankylosaurus magniventris used its appendage in tail-to-tail combat with other males during mating season.
Diet: herbivore; height: 1.7 m (5.5 ft) at the hip; length: 6.25 to 9 m (20.5 to 30 ft).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Tundra
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Bears (Ursidae)
Genus: Arctodus
Species: simus
The short-faced bear was the biggest bear that ever lived.
It was also the biggest land predator in the Americas during the Ice Age.
The skull and teeth of Arctodus simus were more similar to those of a lion than to today's modern bear.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super short-faced bear at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The short-faced bear lived in the Americas from 1.6 million to 10,000 years ago. Like many other species of ancient megafauna, this giant bear became extinct at the end of the Pleistocene era. Possible causes for its extinction include the extinction of many of the creatures it preyed upon, as well as the development of weapons and hunting techniques by early man.
Arctodus simus was almost twice as big as today's brown bear. With its short muzzle, powerful jaws, and formidable teeth, the short-faced bear was a dominant hunter capable of killing large animals. Its prey likely included bison, deer, elk, and camels. This massive beast may have been more diet conscious than today's full-figured bears: Its long legs and straight toes, while enabling it to run fast, also gave the short-faced bear a more slender profile.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.7 m (5.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, up to 3.4 m (11 ft) when upright; weight: up to 900 kg (2,000 lb).

cell.color: Conservation Status:
Extinct
Wetlands
Madagascar

Class: Birds (Aves)
Order: Ratites (Struthioniformes)
Family: Elephant Birds (Aepyornithidae)
Genus: Aepyornis
Species: maximus
The elephant bird was by far the heaviest bird that ever lived.
BFF (best friends forever): Bones of the elephant bird have often been discovered near bones of the hippopotamus.

At more than 30 cm (12 in) long and with a circumference of over 1 m (3 ft), the elephant bird's eggs were larger than any dinosaur egg discovered to date. A single egg from this bird could feed an entire family!
Aepyornis means "tall bird."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super elephant bird at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The elephant bird lived on the island of Madagascar and may have survived until the arrival of the first humans there. Aepyornis maximus became extinct about 350 years ago, possibly due to deforestation of the island and colonization. Although there is little evidence it was hunted extensively for food, elephant bird eggshells found in fire remains suggest humans probably stole eggs from undefended nests to scramble for breakfast. The explorer Marco Polo wrote of a giant bird that could pick up an elephant, fly high into the air, and then drop it to its death. Although his story may have played a part in giving the elephant bird its name, it was certainly a tall tale. Like the ostrich, the elephant bird was a ratite: It could not fly.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.4 to 2.7 m (8 to 9 ft) tall; weight: up to 450 kg (1,000 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Grassland
Southern Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bodivae)
Genus: Hippotragus
Species: leucophaeus

Are you blue? Although Bluebucks found in museums today show no blue color, its name reflects descriptions of live animals. The blue tone may have come from the combination of its black and yellow hairs and the sheen of its dark skin.
Just four preserved and mounted Bluebuck skins, two skulls, and miscellaneous bones remain in museums from what was a thriving population 2,000 years ago.
Two living relatives of the Bluebuck are the Roan Antelope and the Sable Antelope, both of which are classified as "horse antelopes" because of their size and horselike body.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super bluebuck at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Bluebuck was the first South African mammal species to become extinct in modern history. When European immigrants entered the region in the 17th century, Bluebucks may have already been on the decline. Europeans further thinned Bluebuck populations through hunting and the rapid conversion of grassland to farmland, accelerating the extinction of this already-threatened antelope. The last known Bluebuck was killed by a hunter around 1800.
The Bluebuck, also called the blue antelope, looked similar to other species in the antelope family. It had two medium-length sweeping horns, no mane, and a darker coat on top with a white underbelly. Hippotragus leucophaeus lived in the southwestern coastal area of South Africa and roamed the region's well-watered grasslands. The delicate Bluebuck may have preferred blossoms to bushes: According to modern research, the particular grasslands that this species inhabited were -- and are today -- some of the most biologically rich lands on Earth. Not only is the soil especially fertile, but the plant life is also colored by an abundance of flowers, mostly of the daisy family.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1 m (3.5 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 160 kg (350 lb).

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Grassland
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Camels (Camelidae)
Genus: Titanotylopus
Species: spatulus
The giant camel was nearly twice the size of the modern camel. Appropriately, it was originally called Gigantocamelus.
Titanotylopus spatulus's large canine teeth were different from those of today's camel. And it had one other sad difference: The giant camel had no lacrimal vacuities -- it could not cry.
Titanotylopus means "giant knobby-foot," a reference to this big camel's size and its pad-toed feet. Spatulus refers to its broad, flat (spatulalike) incisor teeth.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super giant camel at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Titanotylopus spatulus lived in North America in the Miocene and Pleistocene eras. An extremely large ancestor of the modern camel, the giant camel traveled widely across the United States. Fossils have been found in Texas, Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and Arizona. It resembled the modern camel and included standard camel luggage -- its well-known hump. Its hump and padded toes were probably two or three times the size of today's camels.
Diet: herbivore; size: 3.5 m (11.5 ft) tall at the shoulder.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Extinct
Boreal Forest
North America

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores Carnivora
Family: Cats (Felidae)
Genus: Smilodon
Species: fatalis
The better to eat you with: Smilodon fatalis could open its mouth far wider than today's lion -- 120 degrees to the lion's mere 65 degrees.
The saber-toothed cat's canine teeth were up to 18 cm (7 in) long -- much longer than the blade of an average steak knife.
Its name means "knife tooth."
Many Smilodon fatalis fossils have been found in the La Brea Tar Pits in Los Angeles, California.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super saber-toothed cat at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Saber-toothed cats lived in both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, beginning about 40 million years ago. They became extinct around 11,000 years ago.
The saber-toothed cat, commonly called the saber-toothed tiger, was a large, powerful cat about the size of a lion. It had long, curved canine teeth shaped like sabers. Scientists have identified the fossils of three kinds of saber-toothed cats that coexisted in North America. The best known was Smilodon, recognized by its long, finely serrated canine teeth. Because its short, muscular legs provided power but not speed, Smilodon fatalis probably fed on slow-moving prey such as American mastodons. It would use its vicious, knifelike canines to deliver a fatal wound to the belly, throat, or neck of its prey. Some scientists believe the size of a saber-toothed cat's teeth may have helped it establish dominance among other cats or attract a mate, similar to the function of horns and antlers in other male animals.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.2 m (4 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 200 kg (440 lb).

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed UngulatesArtiodactyla
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Bos
Species: promigenius
No bull! The aurochs' horns could grow up to 1 m (3 ft) long.
Aurochs horns were widely used as drinking vessels for many centuries.
The aurochs was commonly depicted in Paleolithic or Old Stone Age cave paintings found in France and Spain.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super aurochs at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The aurochs, an immense species of wild ox, was a direct ancestor of modern domestic cattle. It was hunted aggressively by humans in part because it competed with domestic cattle for food, but also because its occasional interbreeding with domestic cattle disrupted development of domestic cattle lines. The aurochs population declined as its wild habitat decreased with the growth of farms and cities. The last aurochs died in 1627.
The habitat of Bos primigenius extended across Europe and North Africa to Asia, and was domesticated in Asia around 6000 BC. By 2000 BC, domesticated aurochs appeared in Greece and perhaps in India. This domesticated line eventually spread to Switzerland and Germany, and then to the British Isles. After the late 13th century, most of the aurochs population that remained could be found only in Poland. A few cattle breeds, including Highland cattle from Scotland, resemble their distant relative, the aurochs.
What does the aurochs have in common with today's antelopes, goats, and hippos? They are all even-toed ungulates. "Ungulate" means they have hoofs, and an even-toed ungulate has an even number of hoofs (toes) on each foot, most with two hoofs per foot but some with four.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2 m (6.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, and more than 3 m (10 ft) long; weight: more than 1,000 kg (2,200 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)

Family: Deer (Cervidae)
Genus: Eucladoceros

Growing, growing ... gone: Antlers grow faster than any other substance in the animal kingdom, usually reaching their full size in three months before shedding.
This deer's antlers could grow to a combined width of up to 1.7 m (5.6 ft).
Eucladoceros means "well-branched antler."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super bush-antlered deer at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Eucladoceros dicranios thrived across Europe and Asia during the Pleistocene era. It became extinct about 50,000 years ago. The first bush-antlered deer fossil was discovered in Italy in 1841.
This ancient, regal-looking deer was crowned with the most elaborate set of antlers in the deer family. The two pedicles branched out from the top of its head, each ending in twelve tines. As with other antlered creatures, the bush-antlered deer used its massive antler array not only as a weapon against rivals but also to attract a mate.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.8 m (6 ft) tall at the shoulder, up to 2.5 m (8 ft) long.

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Deinonychus
Species: antirrhopus
Deinonychus means "terrible claw" -- an apt description for one of its most terrifying features!
Deinonychus was the most important dinosaur fossil ever discovered. It changed scientist's belief that dinosaurs were slow and plodding, and introduced the idea that some may have been warm-blooded.
This dinosaur's bones are hollow, similar to those of a modern bird.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super deinonychus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Deinonychus antirrhopus lived during the Cretaceous Period. Until its discovery, dinosaurs were thought to be slow-moving herbivores. By contrast, this predator was swift and agile, and probably hunted its prey in packs. Deinonychus had an enormous claw on the second toe of each hind foot. Scientists once thought it used the claw in a slashing movement to kill its prey. New research shows this dinosaur more likely used it to stab and hold down prey while tearing it to shreds with its razor-sharp teeth. In any case, when Deinonychus is on the rampage -- look out!
Diet: carnivore; size: 3 m (10 ft) long; weight: 80 kg (180 lb).

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Crocodiles (Crocodilia)
Family: Alligators (Alligatoroidea)
Genus: Deinosuchus
Species: hatcheri
Deinosuchus' skull alone was more than 2 m (6.7 ft) long.

Unlike today's crocodile species, which tend to live in either freshwater or saltwater habitats, Deinosuchus fossils have been found in freshwater and saltwater environments, suggesting this creature enjoyed both.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super deinosuchus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Deinosuchus hatcheri lived in Texas during the Upper Cretaceous Period. It belonged to the group Eusuchia, the true crocodiles. Deinosuchus was larger than even the biggest of the modern living reptiles (the saltwater crocodile of Australia and Southern and Southeast Asia), and was one of the largest crocodilians that ever existed. In fact, scientists continue to argue which crocodilian was the largest: Deinosuchus or Sarcosuchus, another immense creature that lived in South America and Africa.
Deinosuchus was much like the modern crocodile. It very likely lived in similar habitats, followed equivalent mating patterns, and exhibited the same hunting characteristics of today's crocs, including the dramatic grab-and-roll technique for which crocodiles are famous. But its diet probably included one treat today's crocodiles never get to snack on -- fresh dinosaur meat!
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 12 m (40 ft) long.

Class: Synapsids (Synapsida)
Order: Spined Lizards (Pelycosauria)
Family: Carnivorous Pelycosaurs(Sphenacodontidae)
Genus: Dimetrodon
Species: angelensis
In spite of its size and appearance, Dimetrodon wasn't a dinosaur; it is classified as a pelycosaur and lived millions of years before dinosaurs even existed.
Lizard? No, it isn't related to lizards, either; it is classified as having been more mammalian than reptilian.
Its sail didn't just make Dimetrodon look cool, it actually made it be cool by regulating body temperature.
Dimetrodon means "two-measure teeth," referring to its teeth of two different sizes.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super dimetrodon at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Dimetrodon angelensis lived during the Permian Period and became extinct about 256 million years ago. The tall sail on its back, its trademark feature, increased the size of its surface skin by up to 50 percent. This flashy sail may have been used to attract a mate. Unlike the free-floating bony structures found on the backs of some ancient creatures, the spines that held up Dimetrodon's sail were attached to individual vertebra. Dimetrodon was one of the first animals to have teeth of different sizes, which made it easier to eat a variety of animals. Although it likely chased its prey on land, Dimetrodon may also have waded in streams to catch fish. Dimetrodon may have been manner conscious: Although many similarly sized creatures swallowed their prey whole, Dimetrodon chewed its meals before swallowing.
Diet: carnivore: size: up to 3.5 m (11.5 ft) long.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Diprotodonts (Diprotodontia)
Family: Marsupials Diprotodontidae
Genus: Diprotodon
Species: optatum
This ancient Australian creature was the biggest marsupial that ever lived. It was related to the kangaroo but was the size of a present-day rhinoceros!
Its skull alone was about 1 m (3 ft) in length.
Diprotodon means "two first teeth." It had flat teeth by its cheeks for chewing plants and long front teeth for cutting and digging up plants.
Surviving relatives of the Diprotodon include the wombat and the koala.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super diprotodon at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Diprotodon optatum became extinct some 40,000 to 50,000 years ago, due to a combination of causes that probably included climate change, hunting by early man, and human use of fire, which changed the landscape and ecosystem. Fossils of these animals have been found only in Australian Pleistocene deposits.
Like the kangaroo, the Diprotodon had a pouch it used to carry its young. Unlike the kangaroo, it used all four legs for walking. Its head was similar in shape to that of today's wombat, and its huge body ended in a tiny, thin tail. This stocky marsupial may have been community minded, living with others of its kind in herds.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.7 m (5.6 ft) tall, 3 m (10 ft) long from nose to tail; weight: up to 2,500 kg (5,500 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Class: Birds (Aves)
Order: Pigeons (Columbiformes)
Family: Dodos (Raphidae)
Genus: Raphus
Species: cucullatus

Stone soup: Known to have subsisted largely on fruit, accounts by sailors who visited the island indicate this bird may also have eaten fish as well as another, less-popular menu item -- rocks. Scientists speculate the rocks may have aided digestion.
This bird's name was likely derived from the Portuguese word duodo, meaning 'silly' or 'stupid.'
The obscure dodo became better known to many people after its appearance in Lewis Carroll's fanciful Alice's Adventures in Wonderland in 1865.
The dodo's living relatives include pigeons and doves.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super dodo at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Mauritius dodo was a large, flightless bird that once inhabited the forests of the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean. Larger than a turkey, weighing up to 23 kg (50 lb), this fruit-eating bird had a large hooked bill, undeveloped wings, and short, thick, yellow legs. It laid a single, large egg in a ground nest made of grass. The dodo was first reported in 1598 by Dutch colonizers, who characterized it as sluggish and unafraid of humans. Having lived as the largest creature in an island environment without predators, the dodo didn't recognize this new threat. This soon changed, as humans became the most significant predator of these flightless creatures. Dodos were last observed in 1681. Their speedy extinction is also attributed in part to animals imported to Mauritius by human settlers, including pigs, cats, rats, and monkeys, which destroyed many of the dodo nests, eggs, and young. Until recently only a few fossil bones of the bird had been discovered, and, even though it existed during modern times, very little was known about this strange creature. In 2005, Dutch researchers found a large trove of dodo bones, including full adults and chicks, on Mauritius that will aid in uncovering more details of this bird.
The dodo is best known for its humorous appearance. It had a large, oddly shaped, hooked bill; undeveloped wings similar to those found on penguins, unsuitable for flight; short yellow legs; and a silly tuft of feathers on its tail end. Although most depictions of Raphus cucullatus show this shy bird as being fat and stocky, the wild dodo may have been quite slim, about half the size of its commonly reported girth. Dodos were introduced to the general public after being imported to Europe, where, it is speculated, they became more rotund in captivity.
Diet: herbivore; size: about 1 m (3 ft) tall; weight: up to 23 kg (50 lb).
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Edentates (Edentata)
Family: Armadillos (Glyptodontidae)
Genus: Doedicurus
Species: clavicaudatus
Doedicurus was about the size of the modern armadillo's most common predator: the small family automobile.
Doedicurus means "pestle tail." It was so named because the bony tail without its spikes resembled a pestle.
Some Doedicurus fossils have dents in their carapaces, indicating that males may have used their tails to fight one another during mating season.
Modern relatives of the Doedicurus include the armadillo, sloth, and anteater.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super doedicurus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Doedicurus, an immense armadillo, was one of the Pleistocene megafauna that thrived in the southern Americas until 15,000 years ago. It probably succumbed to climate changes during the Holocene extinction at the beginning of the modern era. Doedicurus clavicaudatus inhabited woodlands and grasslands, grazing on a variety of vegetation and possibly digging for roots and tubers.
Unlike modern armadillos, Doedicurus had a long, bony tail that ended in a dangerous, macelike array of spikes. Its domed carapace of 1800 armored plates was 2.5 cm (1 in) thick and covered a protective layer of fat, which made it nearly impervious to attack. Its enormous size limited the number of predators that could take it on. But its size could also be a detriment: Doedicurus was a heavy, lumbering glyptodont that could get wedged between rocks and stuck in mud, leaving it defenseless and vulnerable to attack by predators such as Smilodon, the saber-toothed cat. The two beasts likely crossed paths after South America collided with North America around 2.5 million years ago, at which time northern carnivores such as Smilodon headed south while southerners such as Doedicurus migrated north, in an event called the Great Faunal Interchange.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.5 m (5 ft) tall, 4 m (13 ft) long; weight: 1,500 kg (3,306 lb).

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Elephants (Proboscidea)
Family: Elephants (Elephantidae)
Genus: Elephas
Species: falconeri
The dwarf Sicilian elephant was the smallest elephant that ever lived.
A full-grown dwarf Sicilian elephant probably weighed about the same as a newborn Asian elephant.
Strange relations: The sea cow, a marine mammal, is a distant relative of the elephant. It broke from the proboscidian line about 40 million years ago.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super dwarf Sicilian elephant at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Elephas falconeri lived during the Pleistocene Period and became extinct during the last glaciation. While many extinct Pleistocene creatures were extremely large versions of animals living today, some, like the dwarf Sicilian elephant, were much smaller than their modern counterparts -- in this case, the modern Asian elephant. This tiny pachyderm probably evolved from a much larger European elephant species that migrated south when the Mediterranean Sea was at a very low level. When the sea level rose, Elephas falconeri became isolated on the island of Sicily. Like some other ancient animals, it underwent a process called "insular dwarfism": Animals isolated on islands can become smaller over many generations, if a lack of predators makes it unnecessary to maintain a large size and smallness is an advantage if food is not abundant. Dwarf elephants also lived elsewhere in the Mediterranean -- on Malta, Cyprus, Crete, Sardinia, some of the Greek islands, and southern Italy.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1 m (3 ft) tall; weight: 100 kg (220 lb).

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Primates (Primata)
Family: Hominids (Hominidae)
Genus: Gigantopithecus
Species: blacki
Gigantopithecus was the biggest ape that ever lived.
Its closest living relative is the orangutan.
Some people maintain that Gigantopithecus did not die out, but migrated across the frozen Bering Strait to North America to become the basis of legends about the Sasquatch or "Bigfoot."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super gigantopithecus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Gigantopithecus lived in Southeast Asia until about 100,000 years ago. This giant ape's extinction was likely due to a number of factors, including climate change and competition for the bamboo that made up the bulk of its diet. The emergence of early hominids, such as Homo erectus, may have added to the competition.
This big ape was probably a ground dweller, as it was much too heavy to have moved through the trees like today's monkeys. It likely supported itself on its knuckles as it walked. In spite of its ferocious looks, Gigantopithecus blacki wouldn't hurt a fly: It was a vegetarian. This immense beast had to consume huge quantities of plants in order to fuel its massive system, and it had just the right kind of teeth for the job -- large molars housed in big jaws. In fact, the only fossils so far recovered of this creature have been jawbones and teeth. Scientists have used these fossils to extrapolate the size, shape, and habits of this immense creature, largely by comparisons to fossils of similar species.
Diet: herbivore; size: 3 m (10 ft) tall; weight: up to 500 kg (1,100 lb).

Hoofin' it: Rather than the standard claws found on most dinosaurs, the unusual feet of the Kentrosaurus were more like hoofs.
The dangerous spikes along its back and tail grew up to 0.3 m (1 ft) long.
Kentrosaurus means "pointed lizard."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super kentrosaurus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
This dinosaur of the Jurassic Period became extinct about 150 million years ago. The Kentrosaurus sported heavy armor: It had plates and long spikes along its back and tail, and a spike that protruded from each shoulder that it used to protect itself from predators. Unlike similar ornamentation found on other dinosaurs, the Kentrosaurus' plates and spikes were not connected to its bone structure. This slow-moving dinosaur walked on all four feet, but it could rise up on its hind legs to reach higher vegetation.
Diet: herbivore; size: 5.5 m (18 ft) long; weight: 1,814 kg (4000 lb).
