No lyin'! Panthera leo spelaea was the biggest cat that ever roamed the Earth -- about 30 percent bigger than the modern African lion.
Cave lions may have existed in the Balkans just 2,000 years ago, long after the species disappeared from most of Europe and Asia.
Paleolithic man painted images of the cave lion -- in caves.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super cave lion at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The cave lion lived during the Pleistocene era, and its habitat included much of Europe, Africa, and Asia until its extinction around 10,000 years ago. Humans successfully hunted it and may have contributed to its extinction. The extinction of many of the animals Panthera leo spelaea preyed upon may have hastened the disappearance of this species. Also called the European or Eurasian cave lion, this massive cat lived in natural caves during the winter. Its size, speed, and strength made it a formidable predator. Its prey included such herbivores as primitive horses and bison, and possibly even humans.
The male cave lion was unadorned with the stylish ruff of mane and matching tail worn by today's modern lions, going instead for the sleeker look of a major predator. Its one concession to fashion could be found in its coat, which it probably changed with the seasons, becoming white in winter to blend into its snowy habitat.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.5 m (4.9 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: up to 320 kg (705 lb).

This large, shaggy mammal may have enjoyed spending time in lakes and swamps.
Big nose? The American mastodon is of the order Proboscidea, meaning "long-snouted."
Its coat could grow up to about 18 cm (7 in) long.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super American mastodon at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
This elephantlike creature roamed the spruce forests of North America until about 12,500 years ago, when it became extinct. Early man hunted the mastodon and may have contributed to its extinction. Well-preserved American mastodon fossils have been found throughout North America, especially in the northeastern and Great Lakes regions of the United States. Part of the extinct genus Mammut, American mastodons belong to the family Mammutidae, which originated in North Africa 30 to 40 million years ago.
Although Mammut americanum -- with its shaggy brown coat, stocky legs, huge head, and flexible trunk -- looked like and is distantly related to the woolly mammoth, it's a distinctly different animal. The American mastodon was distinguished by nearly horizontal tusks and conical-shaped teeth. Its long tusks helped it to break tree branches, and its blunt teeth were adept at chewing the tough leaves that were a central part of its food intake.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.5 to 3 m (8 to 10 ft) tall at the shoulder; weight: 3,500 to 5,400 kg (7,700 to 12,000 lb).

Protarchaeopteryx means "ancient early wing," a reference to this dinosaur's connection to birds.
Which came first? The discovery of Protarchaeopteryx robusta reinforced the theory that birds evolved from dinosaurs.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super protarchaeopteryx at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Protarchaeopteryx lived from the Jurassic to the Cretaceous Period, and became extinct about 121 million years ago. This groundbreaking dinosaur was only recently discovered: It was first unearthed in the mid-1990s. The feathered Protarchaeopteryx looked more like a bird than a dinosaur. In fact, it is considered by some scientists to be a missing link in the evolution between dinosaurs and birds. Although Protarchaeopteryx robusta could not fly, its long legs suggest it could run very fast.
Diet: unknown; size: 1 m (3 ft) long; weight: 4 kg (10 lb).

The quagga's name comes from a native South African word for zebra, the sound of which is an onomatopoeia -- it resembles the animal's barking call.
Anything but plaid: Unlike the zebra, whose entire body is striped, the quagga's stripes clothed only the front of its body.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can not adopt a quagga. You may breed quaggas, but the only way to acquire one is at the
Extinct Research Lab,
or by unlocking it with the Extinct Release Program award.
Quaggas were native to southern Africa and were plentiful until the late 1600s, when European colonists in Africa hunted them for their meat and hides, and also for sport. By the late 1870s, the wild quagga population was wiped out. What remained had been sent to zoos in Europe. The last quagga died in captivity in 1883, at the Amsterdam Zoo.
Quaggas were likely sociable creatures that moved in herds of 30 to 50 animals. They grazed on desert grasses and sometimes traveled in single file. Of the three species of
zebras
that exist, Equus quagga was related to the plains zebras that roam the grasslands of Africa today.
Diet: herbivore; size: 1.4 m (4.5 ft) tall at the shoulder, 2.5 m (8 ft) long.

The woolly rhinoceros' longest horn could grow up to 1 m (3 ft) in length.
Like modern-day rhinos, the woolly rhinoceros lived alone or in small family groups.
Possibly reflecting its importance to early humans, many images of the woolly rhinoceros have been found painted on cave walls.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super woolly rhinoceros at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Early humans hunted the woolly rhinoceros, and it became extinct about 8,000 to 10,000 years ago. Many frozen remains of the woolly rhinoceros have been discovered, some well preserved in oil-saturated soil.
This member of the Pleistocene megafauna was similar in build to the modern rhinoceros, but it was well insulated with fat and covered in a thick layer of long, shaggy hair, which helped it survive in the cold, snowy conditions found across northern Europe and Asia. Coelodonta antiquitatis had two horns, one longer than the other. The woolly rhinoceros may have been a gardener at heart: It mowed the grass with its short teeth and sometimes using its long horn to dig up plants for dinner.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2 m (6 ft) tall at the shoulder, 3 to 3.8 m (10 to 12.5 ft) long.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Giraffes (Giraffidae)
Genus: Sivatherium

How's the weather up there? Sivatherium was the largest member of the giraffe family that ever lived.
Its ossicones were much larger than those of a modern giraffe, but its neck and legs were much shorter.
The saber-toothed cat may have been the Sivatherium's principal predator.
Its closest living relative is the okapi, or forest giraffe.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super sivatherium at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Sivatherium's habitat extended from Africa to Europe and southern Asia, until it became extinct about 8,000 years ago. Although it was a member of the giraffe family, Sivatherium maurusium looked more like a heavily built antelope with a wide, almost mooselike snout. Unlike the long and lean giraffe, the Sivatherium's body was stout and its legs were relatively short. Its powerful shoulders and short, strong neck supported a broad, heavy head with wide ossicones, or hair-covered horns. Not content with one set of ossicones, the Sivatherium had an extra pair of bony growths that protruded above its eyes.
Diet: herbivore; size: 2.2 m (7 ft) tall at the shoulder.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Edentates (Xenarthra)
Family: Sloths (Megatheriidae)
Genus: Megatherium
Species: americanum
Megatherium means "giant beast," a good name for a sloth the size of a modern bull elephant!
It had huge, curving claws that were up to 30 cm (12 in) long.
The shape of its claws forced Megatherium americanum to walk on the sides of its feet, like modern anteaters.
Its living relatives include tree sloths, armadillos, and anteaters.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super giant ground sloth at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The giant ground sloth became extinct about 8,000 years ago. It ranged across the Americas, from Texas all the way south to Argentina. This gigantic, fur-covered sloth was a quadruped, but it could walk on its hind legs by steadying itself with its enormous tail. Some scientists believe this sloth may have been omnivorous, scavenging meat from animals killed by saber-toothed cats and other prehistoric predators. Megatherium americanum had long claws which it used to pull down leafy branches and dig up plants. With its immense size and formidable claws, the giant ground sloth had little to fear in the way of predators and could feed unhindered during the day.
Diet: herbivore/omnivore; size: 6 m (20 ft) tall when upright; weight: 3,800 kg (8,400 lb).

North America

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Bird-hipped Dinosaurs (Ornithischia)
Family: Stegosaurs (Stegosauridae)
Genus: Stegosaurus
Species: stenops
In brain-to-size ratio, the Stegosaurus had the smallest brain of any dinosaur. It was roughly the size of a walnut!
Its name means "narrow-faced roof lizard," which may refer to the early theory that the Stegosaurus' trademark plates lay flat against its back, like a roof.
Stegosaurus was declared the state dinosaur of Colorado in 1982.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super stegosaurus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Stegosaurus lived during the Jurassic Period and was the only plated dinosaur ever found in western North America. It had 17 attractive, triangular dermal plates, similar to those found in modern crocodiles and some lizards, along the length of its spine. Stegosaurus stenops' weapon of choice was its tail, which was adorned with four vicious-looking spikes. In spite of its impressive weaponry, it became extinct about 145 million years ago.
Diet: herbivore; size: 7 m (23 ft) long; weight: 2,722 kg (6,000 lb).

Class: Archosauria
Order: Saurischia
Family: Tyrannosauridae
Genus: Stokesosaurus
Species: clevelandi
The Stokesosaurus was named after a geologist whose last name was Stokes.
Its fossils have been found only in the state of Utah, in the United States.
Known for its lack of visual acuity, sometimes the stokesosaurus will put on glasses when it can't see.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super stokesosaurus at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
This theropod lived during the Jurassic Period and became extinct about 145 million years ago. The Stokesosaurus is a mysterious creature; very little is known about this dinosaur. In fact, only a few bones, including a hip bone, a few vertebrae, and a partial braincase, have been found so far. Its sole claim to fame: Stokesosaurus clevelandi may be related to the very popular Tyrannosaurus rex.
Diet: carnivore; size: 2.1 m (7 ft) high, 4 m (13 ft) long.

Tasmania

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Dasyuromorphia)
Family: Marsupials (Thylacinidae)
Genus: Thylacinus
Species: cynocephalus
The thylacine was the largest carnivorous marsupial that ever existed.
Thylacinus cynocephalus is also called the Tasmanian tiger or Tasmanian wolf.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super thylacine at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Native to Australia and New Guinea, the thylacine also inhabited the island of Tasmania (south of eastern Australia). Thylacine cynocephalus's extinction was due to several causes, including disease and competition by wild dogs, but most notably it was hunted by farmers and bounty hunters, who saw it as a pest. The last known thylacine died in an Australian zoo in 1936.
Although the thylacine was a marsupial, it was the size of a small wolf and looked like a dog -- except for the parts that looked like a kangaroo: It had a tapered hind end and a long, stiff, kangaroolike tail, which accounted for about half its length. It could balance upright and hop on its hind legs, stabilized by its rigid tail, and also had a ready-made pouch on its abdomen in which it carried its young. Its short, coarse, brownish hair was reminiscent of yet another animal, with its distinctive black tigerlike stripes across the back. While the kangaroo is an herbivore, the thylacine's diet was markedly wolflike: It was a carnivore.
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 1.3 m (4 ft) long, including the tail; weight: 15 to 33 kg (33 to 66 lb).

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Utahraptor
Species: ostrommaysorum
The Utahraptor's famous claw could grow up to 23 cm (almost 9 in) long!
It was the largest member of the Dromaeosauridae family.
Utahraptor means "Utah thief."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super utahraptor at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
The Utahraptor lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 119 million years ago. Utahraptor ostrommaysorum is the only known species of Utahraptor. This theropod walked upright on massive hind limbs, and, like its cousins Deinonychus and Velociraptor, it featured a menacing claw on the second toe of each foot that it used to kill its prey. Utahraptor walked with the sharp claws raised above the ground to protect its most valuable weapon.
Diet: carnivore; size: up to 6.5 m (22 ft) long; weight: 700 kg (1,500 lb).

Class: Sauropods (Sauropsida)
Order: Theropods (Theropoda)
Family: Raptors (Dromaeosauridae)
Genus: Velociraptor
Species: mongoliensis
Although the Velociraptors' hands were very dexterous, don't worry -- it still couldn't open your bedroom door.
The Velociraptor is a Dromeaosaridae, which means "running lizard."

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super velociraptor at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Velociraptor mongoliensis lived during the Cretaceous Period and became extinct about 70 million years ago. It belongs to a group of dinosaurs that has been linked to Archaeopteryx -- also known as ancient birds. In fact, these dinosaurs are often referred to as "raptors," a term that is also used to describe modern birds of prey such as vultures and falcons. Much smaller than its immense cousin Deinonychus, wolf-size Velociraptor walked on its hind legs and used its long tail for balance. It was agile and quick. Although its hindquarters were much larger than its puny arms, the Velociraptor made up for their lack of size with nimble hands that it used to grasp its struggling dinner. Velociraptor is best known for the vicious, curved claw on each of its hind feet that it used to kill its prey.
Diet: carnivore; size: 1.8 m (6 ft) long; weight: 45 kg (100 lb).

Falkland Islands

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Canines (Canidae)
Genus: Dusicyon
Species: australis
Instead of howling like the foxes it resembled, the Warrah is said to have barked like a dog.
It was the only mammal native to the Falkland Islands, off the southern coast of Argentina, and was also known as the Falkland Islands Fox.
Its name means "foolish dog of the south" and refers to the Warrah's apparent lack of fear of humans.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super warrah at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
Despite the Warrah's probable diet of penguins, ground-nesting birds, grubs and insects, and vegetation, immigrants to the animal's native Falkland Islands saw it as a threat to domestic cattle and sheep. Its tawny coat was also prized for its thickness. Settlers trapped, poisoned, and shot Dusicyon australis in large numbers. The last known Warrah was killed in 1876.
With its reddish-brown coat and white-tipped tail, the Warrah resembled other species of fox or a small wolf. Ancient cavemen may have warmed up to this best friend: The Warrah's comparative tameness has led some to suggest that it may have been brought to the Falkland Islands by prehistoric man and domesticated, retaining some of its domestic behavior after the original human inhabitants left.
Diet: carnivore/omnivore; size: 60 cm (24 in) tall at the shoulder.

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Pigs (Suidae)
Genus: Metrideochoerus
Species: andrewsi
Pigheaded: Like the modern warthog, the long, wide head of the giant warthog had two pairs of sharp, defensive tusks that pointed sideways and curved upwards, and two pairs of wartlike protuberances.
The giant warthog's habits were also likely to have been similar to those of today's warthog. Usually active during the day, this giant creature probably slept the night away in a burrow.

LOC_STRING.cell:
You can create the super giant warthog at the Extinct Research Lab after finding and assembling its fossil pieces. To learn more, click on this link to view the entry for the Extinct Research Lab.
This extinct genus of pig lived in Africa during the Pleistocene Period. It resembled the modern warthog but was somewhat larger. Based on the shape of its molars, Metridiochoerus andrewsi is believed to have fed, like its modern counterpart, on grass, berries, bark, roots, and carrion. It was likely family oriented, with a social life similar to the modern warthog's: One or two females with young formed small groups, which a male might join briefly during mating season; young males formed bachelor groups, but older males were solitary.
Diet: Omnivore; size: 1.5 m (5 ft) long; weight: up to 160 kg (350 lb).
